newsitem.title: USA: Lehman cites market, rates for Q3 rev fall.
newsitem.headline: Lehman cites market, rates for Q3 rev fall.

text.p: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc said volatile market conditions and delayed underwritings were among the key reasons the company failed to extend a more than year-long streak of quarterly revenue growth.

Lehman's third quarter net revenues, which represents total revenues less interest expenses, amounted to $722 million, short of both the $750 million in net revenues it posted a year ago and the second quarter's $833 million.

"Volatile conditions in the debt and equity markets, as well as seasonal softness in several businesses, interrupted the five consecutive quarters of higher revenues we had posted," Lehman Chairman and Chief Executive Richard Fuld said in a statement.
Lehman also cited the effects of interest rate movements on customer trading volumes and decisions by issuers to delay scheduled underwritings for the decline.
For the quarter, revenues from principal transactions rose to $303 million from $245 million a year ago but investment banking revenues fell to $237 million from $251 million.
Commissions revenues fell to $77 million from $116 million while interest and dividend revenues rose to $2.96 billion from $2.83 billion.
However, interest expenses for the quarter rose to $2.86 billion from $2.70 billion, more than offsetting the increase in interest and dividend related revenues.
Other revenues fell to $4 million from $11 million.

Below the revenue line, the picture was somewhat better, with Lehman's return on common equity rising to 9.0 percent from 8.5 percent a year ago. Still, that was well short of the 13.4 percent figure posted in the second quarter.
Lehman's pre-tax margin for the quarter was 16.0 percent, down from the second quarter's 20.2 percent level but up from 14.5 percent a year ago.
"While quarterly revenue was off for a number of market related and seasonal reasons, it is important to note that our discipline around expenses remained strong," Fuld said.

Total non-interest expenses for the quarter fell to $606 million from $641 million a year ago, a key reason the company was able to improve quarterly net earnings to $77 million or $0.60 per share from $71 million or $0.52 per share last year.
